BE11:14am

A lot of “If those MPs hadn’t abstained on ‘our’ preferred Brexit choice of ‘X’ we would have won” from all sides of the debate tonight. We need to see compromise and less abstentions from soft Brexiteers/remainers in the next 48 hours into Wednesday’s votes. Then this process really could come to a positive conclusion.

If not it seems likely the government will put the deal to another vote on Thursday. Be prepared for another round of “this makes a hard Brexit more likely” commentary (such as Peston now) despite parliament clearly preferring a long art.50 extension over that. Admittedly the Cabinet meeting tomorrow will hopefully shed more light on what they think about all the options.

Still happy with our EURGBP short.

Here's Deutsche:

JP11:15am

It might not quite be 21 years yet but it feels that way for all of us following Brexit as the House of Commons once again gathered last night to vote on the slimmed down list of options for the indicative votes or as one scribe wrote “vindictive votes”. Every motion failed to achieve a parliamentary majority though. The proposal for a customs union with the EU came the closest yet, losing by a vote of 276-273, while the option for a second referendum came second-best with a 292-280 loss. Some MPs argued for linking the two options into a single proposal later this week, but other members contended that watering down either motion would lose more votes than it would gain. Meanwhile parliament will have another chance to take over Brexit on Wednesday when further set of votes on alternatives are planned.

So with things looking deadlocked in the House of Commons, attention will shift to today’s marathon cabinet meeting, scheduled for 9am to 12pm and then again from 1pm to 3pm. The morning session will be political officials only, no civil servants, meaning that PM May and her team are likely to consider the options including calling for a general election. That’s the base case from DB’s Oliver Harvey, though there is space in the parliamentary timetable for May to bring her WA for a fourth vote tomorrow if she wanted to. Sterling had traded firmer through much of yesterday and was up around +0.52% when New York went home. After the votes, the currency dropped over half a percent and is trading slightly above those levels this morning.

JP11:15am

From Jim Reid and friends.

11:15 am
JP11:16am

No, we haven't a scooby doo either.

BE11:16am

UBS did the election likelihood thing yesterday too.

BE11:16am

General Election may follow Brexit stalemate
The Government's repeated failures to win Parliamentary approval for its Withdrawal Deal have led us to conclude that an early General Election is now more likely, unless the deal already agreed with the EU can somehow be advanced in the coming days. Currently, the only forms of Brexit that a majority in Parliament seems ready to potentially support include features the Prime Minister has repeatedly identified as uncrossable red lines (for example a Customs Union or a confirmatory referendum). If she were to accept these demands, it appears she would risk her most pro-Brexit colleagues not supporting her in a vote of confidence. If she doesn't, she faces the same threat from the majority in Parliament who have already voted to prevent no deal at any time and under any circumstances. A long extension – were one to be agreed without stringent conditions by the EU – might delay this reckoning, we think, but it doesn't change the underlying stalemate and would likely still lead to an early General Election in due course.

There are also reasons why the Government may willingly opt for an Election
Under the Fixed-term Parliaments Act 2011, an early Election can either happen following a vote of no confidence in the Government (if no workable alternative can be formed in the next two weeks), or if 2/3 of MPs vote in favour of holding one. Effectively, the first of these is an election forced on the Government, the second is one volunteered for. As a possible way out of the current impasse, this voluntary route may become more appealing to the current Government than some assume. The Tories are currently ahead in the opinion polls (Figure1), and last week's news that the MPs who left the two main parties have now officially formed a party of their own (Change UK) may increase speculation that the left wing vote could be split. In addition, it seems the Tories will be the only party standing on a manifesto that offers a relatively decisive form of Brexit, while Labour's much softer version could see them effectively competing for (Brexit-driven) votes with the SNP, Liberal Democrats, and Change UK.

If election, an overwhelming Brexit focus could lead to unexpected outcomes
One of the intriguing aspects of the Brexit process is that a large number of constituencies saw a majority vote in the referendum for an outcome their own MP does not favour. Should there be a General Election with an overwhelming focus on Brexit, we believe there could be a stronger tendency than usual for voters to switch to a different party if they feel their own MP has acted against their wishes as expressed in the EU referendum. This lending of votes could have more impact for the Labour party – for illustrative purposes, we look at a uniform 10% swing in all Conservative constituencies where a majority voted to remain, and the same swing in all Labour constituencies where a majority voted to leave. In this scenario, there would be a net gain of 21 seats for the Conservatives, all else equal (net gain of 11 seats from a 5% swing, 9 seats from a 3% swing – Figure 2).

Prolonged Brexit uncertainty and elevated political risk cloud economic outlook
While an early election has been cited as a way of ending Brexit uncertainty, not only will that uncertainty persist throughout the campaign, but currently it seems the only way it might be swiftly resolved at the end of it is if a majority Tory Government that is still committed to the current deal agreed with the EU is returned. We believe any other result would either mean the current impasse effectively continues, or involve renegotiating a different deal virtually from scratch, assuming the EU would be prepared to enter such negotiations. The possibility of a Government with significantly different fiscal and taxation policies will add more uncertainty, and we view an early election as posing a clear and material downside risk to our current GDP forecasts.

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: The company has provided a year end update and confirms that net income is within the previous guided range of €270-300m (UBS €284m vs consensus €292m).
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: There were some concerns around the company’s ability to cut costs in 4Q10 but given the update it is likely that ex fuel unit costs have been reduced c10%.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: No guidance on FY 2020 has been provided. However, Wizz says March trading has been robust and the first quarter has started well with 1Q20 ASK up 18% and RASK up 4%. Furthermore, ex fuel unit costs expected flat in 1Q20.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: Given the material share price fall yesterday on the back of easyJet’s trading update we expect the shares to rebound.

On outlook, the new financial year has started well with Q1 RASK +4% yoy on 18% ASK
growth. This performance is driven by the strength in group’s ancillary business which is
expected to continue into the Summer and also the timing of Easter (which accounts for
c.2.5% of the RASK uplift). Our forecasts for H119 are for a slightly positive increase in
overall RASK which reflects a stronger ancillary RASK performance with some offset for ticket
RASK. Cost ex-fuel is expected to be broadly flat yoy for Q1 against our -1% yoy for FY20,
which will likely see some adjustment.
Overall today’s update is more positive on pricing while slightly higher than
expected on unit cost inflation. As such, our FY20f PAT number of €375m will likely
see downgrades of c.7-10% versus consensus at c.€360m. As we look out further,
we remain comfortable on the group’s performance to deliver unit costs wins aided
by the start of its A321neo delivery programme this year.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Issues on the broader Trent 1000 fleet have been well
documented, though the latest news concerns the Trent 1000-TEN population
of engines. Roll-Royce had indicated at full year results that they had yet to see
any issues on the TEN engines during previous inspections, so this appears a new
development.
Rolls-Royce issued a statement in response to the reports indicating that the
number of affected engines is so far limited. It has commented that sampling of a
small population of Trent 1000-TEN engines flown in arduous conditions has
found that a small number need blades replacing earlier than scheduled. Our
conversations with the company suggest this was viewed as a known risk factor,
and believe it can be covered in existing guidance for Trent 1000 in-service costs
of “around £450m” in 2019 and £350m in 2020.
Whilst there is clearly a risk of further increasing cash costs on the programme if
the number of affected engines expands, we note the TEN is only around 140 of
the total 610 Trent 1000 engines in service, so in-service disruption is likely to be
lower previous issues on the larger Package C population (where a fix has been
certified). Rolls-Royce is already in the process of proactively re-designing the
intermediate pressure compressor blades on the TEN engines, and expects this to
be certified by 3Q19.

Irish Fencer What can you tell me about this Brexit thing?
JP11:35am

UBS are still bullish. Here's Celine Fornaro:

JP11:35am

Rolls-Royce shares have lagged most of its European civil Aerospace peers. The catalysts are no different though: i) RR widebody fleet is likely to benefit from execution issues in the A321neo/737Max deliveries as 79% of the Trent700 fly routes under 3,000Nm particularly in Asia, ii) the widebody orders of 2019 have already outstripped the poor levels of 2018, iii) the delivery on the cash improvement remains on track based on the 2019-21 Long term Incentive Plan just released in the 2018 Annual report with c£2.8bn cumulative FCF at the mid-range and c£3.5bn at the high range. This compares to our c£2.9bn estimate. Next catalysts: 1) more clarity around Brexit, 2) Paris Airshow mid-June with some wide-bodies orders, 3) update on 777-X certification timing – if delayed it could benefit A350-1000

11:35 am
JP11:35am

Raising our FCF estimates on the back of FY18 and FY19 guidanceWe have raised our FCF estimates as we reflect a stronger FCF in 2018 and better 2019 guidance. We have refined our civil Aerospace cash simulation model including raising our flight hours estimates and also reflect working capital tailwinds as well as higher cost reduction benefits. The largest tailwind to Aerospace FCF growth is the A350 which continues to perform well. By the end of 2019 its installed fleet size will be similar to the Trent1000. Our FCF has gone up by c.£70mn pa on av over 2019-23E

JP11:35am

Profit and cost reduction support Power Systems growth, unlike AerospaceP&L metrics remain very complicated and counter-intuitive to asses for the Aerospace performance due to IFRS15 dynamics and capitalised R&D. We focus on divisional cash flows broken down by engine programme. Power Systems has shown good progress in 2018 with some traction in cost reductions. We model 14% growth in EBIT for 2019 supported by an improved order book. Our EPS changes reflect negative contract accounting impact for the 787, latest IFRS16, latest shop visits estimates

BE11:37am

While we may have hoped that the 1000 TEN would be more reliable than
earlier Trent 1000 engines, it is a derivative engine - as is the Trent 7000 for the A330neo - and we believe all versions of the Trent 1000 are covered by the same EASA airworthiness directives. That includes the same inspection regime. In short, the same reliability issues could occur in the 1000 TEN.
Details: We do not know if Singapore Airlines has found deterioration on Turbine Blades - the lesser issue - or Compressor Blades - the more serious issue. As Singapore Airlines was the first to receive 787-10 aircraft, we assume the engines are fitted with the original Turbine/Compressor blades. We assume the engines have not yet been retrofitted with the new blade designs now being rolled out across the fleet.

YouGov results look pretty solid. Revs up 18 per cent, and a whole bunch of adjusted numbers up as well. EBITDA up 55 per cent to £13.2m.

JP11:46am

Peel Hunt seem pleased.

11:46 am
JP11:46am

Divisional performance. Revenues for data products grew 26% organically, driven by strong growth from “Plan and Track” the combined proposition of BrandIndex and Profiles. c£1.3m of custom research revenues have moved into data services, reducing the organic growth of the segment to 9%. Custom Research, which has been less of a focus area for YouGov, had organic growth of 4%. Adj operating margins for data products and custom research both expanded. Margins for data services contracted slightly, but this is a phasing issue which is expected to revert in H2.

JP11:46am

New financial targets. YouGov published financial targets for the new growth strategy, which will be linked to the new LTIP. The targets are a doubling of revenues and adjusted operating margin by the end of FY23 (4x increase in profit). In addition, there is a target for adjusted EPS CAGR in excess of 30% for the period. We are pleased to see YouGov amend its definition of adjusted profit to include IT amortisation and share option costs, a measure the market has been focused on for some time. The financial targets are based on the updated adjusted definition.

JP11:46am

We increase our revenues slightly by 1% for FY19. Operating profits remain broadly unchanged due to continued investment in H2. EPS reduces by 5% due to a higher dilution of shares and also a higher tax charge.
